Docs.summary: Represents a constraint describing the flexion and pointing direction of a subset of fingers.
Docs.remarks:
A constraint refers to a set of fingers, defined by the property, it specifies the direction of these fingers, as defined by the property, and their flexion state (the degree to which a fingers is open or folded), as defined by the property. Note that when the value is set to , the constraint implies no restriction of the direction for fingers mentioned in .
The following code defines a with a single constraint that is actualized when both the index and thumb fingers are open and pointing forward:
var myPose = new HandPose("MyPose", new FingerPose(new[] {Finger.Index, Finger.Thumb}, FingerFlexion.Open, PoseDirection.Forward));
The constraint in the example above restricts the pose of only the index and thumb fingers. As soon as the camera sees a hand whose index and thumb fingers are open and pointing forward, the encompassing object's state-machine can advance to myPose, regardless of the state of the other fingers. To generalize, all the fingers which are not participating in the of a are free to assume any state of flexion and point in any direction (unless constrained by a different instance).
Note that specifying a constraint with a value of (or ) and in parallel a value other than is ill-advised. This is because a folded finger cannot be meaningfully said to point in any particular direction. In addition, the tips of folded fingers are very likely to be hidden from the camera, making the estimated values of their directions unreliable.
Note that instances are mutable until the containing object is registered with the gestures runtime, at which point it becomes frozen and cannot be modified any longer.
